title: Question 19
prompt: In studying earthquakes, seismologists have found that soft soil amplifies, or increases, ground shaking. Other factors that affect the amount of shaking at a particular location include the size of the earthquake and how close the site is to the fault where the earthquake occurs. If Krista is considering building a house in an area that has many earthquakes, which of the following locations is the best place to build?
description: Click the <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
Three factors affect the amount of shaking, which causes earthquake damage. Since soft soil increases shaking, hard soil is better to build on than soft soil. The second factor, the size of the earthquake, cannot be predicted. The third factor is how close the site is to a fault. A site relatively far from the fault where an earthquake occurs will experience less shaking. The site with hard soil relatively far from fault lines is the best building site.
